title: Pythagoras
subtitle: 550 - 500 bce
description: Pythagoras is credited with discovering the mathematical ratios that correspond to musical intervals, laying the groundwork for the study of acoustics. His geometric work included studies on polygons, proportions, figures, and the Pythagorean Theorem.

title: Democritus
subtitle: 440 - 370 bce
description: Democritus posits that everything in the universe is made up of small, indivisible particles called atoms

title: Aristotle
subtitle: 365 - 320 bce
description: Aristotle organized the knowledge of the physical world, including mathematical principals. He developed the syllogism, a form of logical argument that became fundamental to mathematical reasoning.

title: Euclid
subtitle: 300 bce
description: Euclid publishes "Elements", serving as the main textbook for teaching mathematics, especially geometry, until the early 20th century. He also lays the foundation for the study of optics, which ultimately leads to a better understanding of the nature of light.

title: Archimedes
subtitle: 260 - 210 bce
description: Archimedes develops methods for calculating areas and volumes, principles in fluid mechanics, concept of center of gravity, invention of Archimedes screw to raise water

title: Eratosthenes
subtitle: 240 bce
description: Eratosthenes accurately calculated the Earth"s circumference, developed the Sieve of Eratosthenes, an algorithm for finding all prime numbers up to a specified integer, and was among the first to apply mathematical principles to map-making, coining the term "geography".

title: Apollonius
subtitle: 220 - 190 bce
description: Apollonius provides geometric foundations for later work on eclipses by Johannes Kepler with his work on "Conics" (ellipse, parabola, hyperbola)

title: Hipparchus
subtitle: 170 - 130 bce
description: Hipparchus discovers the precession of the equinoxes, and compiles the first known trigonometric table for solving triangles, founding trigonometry

title: Ptolemy
subtitle: 170 ce
description: Ptolemy published "Algamest", a treatise on the apparent motions of stars and planetary paths. He provided a geocentric model of the universe which dominated astronomical thought for centuries.

title: Diophantus
subtitle: 220 - 270 ce
description: Diophantus publishes "Arithmetica", a collection of algebraic problems dealing with polynomial equations and integer solutions. His work laid the foundations for the development of algebra and he is known as the"father of algebra".

title: Aryabhata
description: Aryabhata publishes "Aryabhatiya", where he introduced the concept of zero as a number and discussed the place-value system.

title: Al-Khwarizmi
description: Al-Khwarizmi writes "The Compendious Book on Calculation by Completion and Balancing", introducing the foundations of Algebra. He introduced algorithmic procedures, and the Hindu-Arabic numeral system, the global standard today for numerical representation.

title: Alhazen
description: Alhazen publishes "Book of Optics", laying the foundation for the modern science of optics. He studied the properties of light and vision, including reflection, refraction, and the behavior of lenses. He"s among the first to use the scientific method and empirical evidence.

title: Omar Khayyam
description: Omar Khayyam publishes solutions to many cubics, with solutions limited to positive coefficients, lacking general solution

title: Leonardo of Pisa (Fibonacci)
description: Leonardo of Pisa (Fibonacci) spreads the Hindu-Arabic numeral system in Europe and discovers the Fibonacci sequence, which has applications in various fields of science and mathematics.

title: Luca Pacioli
description: Luca Pacioli publishes "Summa de Arithmetica", concluding a solution to the cubic equation is impossible.

title: Scipione del Ferro
description: Scipione del Ferro finds a method to reliably solve depressed cubics (a subset with no x squared term), tells no one but Antonio Maria Fior.

title: Niccolo Fontana Tartaglia
description: Niccolo Fontana Tartaglia independently discovers the solution to the depressed cubic equation, publishes it in a cryptic poem.

title: Gerolamo Cardano
description: Gerolamo Cardano convinces Tartaglia to share the solution to the depressed cubic. He publishes "Ars Magna" and extends Tartaglia"s method to solve all types of cubics, and Lodovico Ferrari"s solution of the quartic equation. They coin the square roots of negative numbers as "sophistic" numbers.

title: Rafael Bombelli
description: Rafael Bombelli publishes that these imaginary numbers are actually useful in solving cubic equations. However, these numbers are still considered imaginary.

title: Francis Viete
description: Francis Viete publishes "In artem analyticam isagoge", laying the foundation for algebraic notation using letters to represent known and unknown quantities.

title: Rene Descartes
description: Rene Descartes publishes "La Geometrie". He introduces (a, b, c, ...) to denote known quantities and (x, y, z, ...) for unknowns, and Cartesian Geometry which merged algebra and geometry by using algebraic methods to solve geometric problems.

title: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz
description: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, along with Isaac Newton, is credited with developing calculus independently. He also made significant contributions to the field of logic and the binary number system, which is the foundation of virtually all digital computers.

title: Isaac Newton
description: Isaac Newton develops calculus, formulates the three fundamental laws of motion, the law of universal gravitation, and develops a theory of color based on the observation that a prism decomposes white light into the colors of the visible spectrum.

title: John Bernoulli
description: John Bernoulli introduces the term integral to describe the inverse operation of differentiation in calculus. He developed a principle that explains the behavior of fluid flow and is fundamental in aerodynamics and hydrodynamics. He was also instrumental in the early development and solutions of differential equations.

title: Leonhard Euler
description: Leonhard Euler developed the formula which links exponential functions to trigonometric functions and is a cornerstone in complex analysis. Euler"s identity combines five fundamental mathematical constants in a simple equation. He developed Euler"s method for numerically solving ordinary differential equations, discovered several theorems in geometry, the foundations of graph theory, the quadratic reciprocity law, and much more.

title: Augustin-Louis Cauchy
description: Augustin-Louis Cauchy established the foundations of calculus and complex analysis, introducing key concepts like Cauchy"s Theorem, the Integral Formula, and the Convergence Test.

title: Bernhard Riemann
description: Bernhard Riemann develops Riemannian geometry, which laid the groundwork for general relativity, and for the Riemann Hypothesis, a fundamental unsolved problem in number theory.

title: James Clerk Maxwell
description: James Clerk Maxwell formulated the classical theory of electromagnetic radiation, bringing together electricity, magnetism, and light as different manifestations of the same phenomenon.

title: George Boole
description: George Boole lays the foundations for Boolean algebra, a critical component of computer science and logic.

title: Georg Cantor
subtitle: 300 bce
description: Georg Cantor establishes the concept of set theory. His work also led to the understanding of the concept of infinity and different types of infinities in mathematics.

title: Albert Einstein
description: Albert Einstein developed the theory of relativity, one of the two pillars of modern physics (alongside quantum mechanics). He developed special relativity (1905) and then general relativity (1915), which replaced Newton"s theory of gravitation. He provided crucial evidence for quantum theory by demonstrating that light can be thought of as particles (photons) as well as waves with his work on the photoelectric effect, which laid the groundwork for quantum mechanics.

title: John von Neumann
description: Made major contributions to a number of fields, including mathematics (set theory, functional analysis), physics (quantum mechanics, hydrodynamics, and quantum statistical mechanics), economics (game theory), computing (linear programming, self-replicating machines, stochastic computing).

title: Erwin Schrödinger
subtitle: 220 - 190 bce
description: Formulates the Schrödinger equation, a fundamental equation in quantum mechanics. Developed wave mechanics, an alternative formulation of quantum mechanics that describes the behavior of quantum systems using wave functions. Made significant contributions to the understanding of how the eye perceives color.

title: Alan Turing
description: A pioneer in computer science, Turing is best known for the Turing machine, a model of a general-purpose computer, and for his work in breaking the Enigma code during World War II.

title: Kurt Gödel
description: Publishes his incompleteness theorems, showing inherent limitations in every non-trivial axiomatic system. His theorems had profound implications for the philosophy of mathematics and logic.

title: Claude Shannon
description: Publishes "A Mathematical Theory of Communication", laying the groundwork for information theory. Introduced key concepts such as the bit, entropy, and redundancy in communication.

title: John Nash
description: Develops the Nash Equilibrium, a concept in game theory. Made contributions to the theory of nonlinear partial differential equations and singularities in differential geometry.

title: Benjamin Mandelbrot
description: Discovers the Mandelbrot set and coins the term "fractal" to describe these complex geometric shapes that repeat at every scale.

title: Edward Witten
description: Helped in the development of M-theory, an advanced theory in physics. Contributed to quantum field theory, supersymmetry, and quantum gravity.

title: Grigori Perelman
description: Provides proof for Poincare conjecture in the field of topology. Utilized Ricci flow in his work.

title: Terence Tao
description: Co-authored the Green-Tao theorem, stating that there are arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions of prime numbers. Contributed to various fields, including number theory, combinatorics, and partial differential equations.

title: Andrew Wiles
description: Proved Fermat"s last theorem. His proof linked modular forms and elliptic curves, contributing to the field of number theory.
